awd_titl_txt: 2020 National Robotics Initiative Principal Investigators Meeting
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this award is to organize the logistics portion of the annual Principal Investigators (PI) meeting for the National Robotics Initiative (NRI), which was launched in 2011. The PI meeting brings together the community of researchers, companies, and program officers who are actively engaged in the NRI to provide cross-project coordination in terms of common intellectual challenges, methods for education and training, best practices in education, technology transfer and general outreach, and a centralized and lasting repository illustrating the research ideas explored and milestones achieved by the NRI projects. 

The meeting of the Principal Investigators of the National Robotics Initiative will be two days in February 2020 in the vicinity of Washington DC. The format will include presentations by the attending PIs of projects in their final year, a poster session with all other projects, keynote speeches, and panel discussions. Invitations to the meeting will include all PIs with active NRI grants. This award will take care of the venue, travel, A/V, supplies, and many of the personnel involved in organizing the meeting.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this award was to organize the coordination and logistics for the 2020 NRI PI Meeting that was held February 27-28, 2020 at the Renaissance Arlington Capital View, located at 2800 South Potomac Ave., Arlington, Virginia 22202.

NRI-FRR PI meetings bring together the community of researchers, industries, and program officers who are actively engaged in the NRI to provide cross-project coordination.

PI Meeting logistics largely entail finding and negotiating contracts including the facilities/locations, room blocks, food & beverage, Audio-visual, Internet, electricity, poster stands, etc; building, designing, and managing the websites; collecting and manageing meeting registrations; collecting and managing keynote talks and PI project materials (e.g., posters, lightning talks, vidoes, demonstrations); managing incoming project materials and preparing them for PI Meeting programs; post meeting editing and archiving of project artifacts; and creating and analyzing post-meeting surveys. 

The 2020 NRI PI Meeting was attended by two hundred forty-eight (248) community members. The PI worked with Dr. David Miller (lead NSF NRI PD) and Dr. Ella Atkins (University of Michigan, Ann Arbor) – the 2020 program chair. Keynote speakers were Glen Henshaw – the Naval Research Lab’s (NRL) senior space roboticist and the chief roboticist for DARPA’s Robotic Servicing of Geosynchronous Satellites (RSGS) program – and Hanumant Singh – Professor at Northeastern University. Henshaw spoke on the topics of the NRL’s Robotics Servicing of Geosynchronous Satellites capabilities and robotic operations concepts. Singh spoke on the vision for the future of Marine and Polar Robotics over the coming decades. Selected key responses from the post-meeting survey of 54 respondents out of 248 attendees revealed that: 1) 53 out of 54 respondents rated the PI Meeting as “Very Good; 2) On average, about 40 of the 54 respondents were “very satisfied” with the overall logistics, location, and communications for the PI Meeting; and 3) more than half of the respondents were either “satisfied” or “very satisfied” with the overall program sessions. 

Via no cost extensions, funds from 2020 NRI PI Meeting award were also used to cover two virtual NRI-FRR PI Meetings held in March 10-12, 2021 and April 19-21, 2022.  

 Four hundred forty-six (446) attendees out of 454 registrants attended the 2021 NRI-FRR PI Meeting. The PI worked with David Miller (lead NSF PD) and Geoff Hollinger and William Smart – both of Oregon State and the 2021 Co-chairs. Keynote speakers were Allison M. Okamura – Professor in the Mechanical Engineering and Computer Science Departments at Stanford – and Siddartha Srinivasa who is the Director of Robotics AI at Amazon, the Boeing Endowed Professor at The Paul G. Allen School of Computer Science & Engineering at the University of Washington. Okamura spoke on the topic of Soft Robotics for Humanity. Srinavasa spoke on numerous related topics where he invited the audience to ask him anything. Selected key responses from the post-meeting survey of 74 out of 446 online participants revealed that: 1) 67 respondents rated the meeting overall as “Excellent” and “Good” ; 2) 66 of the 74 respondents were either “very satisfied” (highest rating) and “satisfied” (second highest rating) with the overall virtual logistics and communications for the PI Meeting; and 3) 29 of the 33 respondents were either “very satisfied” and “satisfied” with the overall program sessions.

Three hundred forty-seven (347) community members out of 443 registrants attended the 2022 NRI-FRR PI Meeting. The PI worked with Juan Wachs and Erion Plaku who were the NSF NRI PDs at the time, as well, with the 2022 Co-chairs – Marynel Vázquez – a computer scientist and roboticist at Yale and Kostas Bekris – Assistant Professor in Computer Science at Rutgers University. Keynote speakers were Dr. Holly Yanco – Distinguished University Professor, Professor of Computer Science, and Director of the New England Robotics Validation and Experimentation (NERVE) Center at the University of Massachusetts, Lowell – who spoke on the topic of Designing Robots for Humans and Matthew Johnson-Roberson – Director of the Carnegie Mellon Robotics Institute and a Professor in the School of Computer Science – who spoke on the topic of Lesson from the Field: Deep Learning and Machine Perception for Field Robotics. Selected key responses from the post-meeting survey of 74 out of 446 online participants revealed that: 1) 28 out of the 35 respondents rated the meeting overall as “Very Good” and “Good”; 2) About half of the 33 respondents were either “very satisfied” or “satisfied” with the virtual logistics and communications for the PI Meeting; and 3) About half of the 33 respondents were either “very satisfied” and “satisfied” with the overall program sessions.

All post-meeting artifacts, including the program agenda, keynote speakers and talks, meeting organizers, project materials, participant guidance, virtual venue guidance (where relevant), attendees, and registrants are posted to the respective 2020, 2021, and 2022 PI Meeting websites on the CPS VO at https://cps-vo.org.

 

 


Last Modified: 01/28/2024
Modified by: Frankie D King
